ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A solid understanding of water as a natural resource in the 20th century, and related topics of environmental disruption (especially dams), power and access to clean drinking water, "development," "nature," and other similar themes.
Knowledge: So much knowledge about the history of water, capitalism, dams!!!!!!, nature. An awesome class.

This was a writing course, so we learned how to write in depth research papers using primary and secondary sources. I learned a lot about how to write a research paper that is not only informative, but also enjoyable to read.
I learned a lot about the many ways water impacts the environment and human lives.
This course taught me how to properly write a historical narrative, digging through archival research to develop a story.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: readings were fascinating, discussions lively, our reading responses and other papers were enjoyable and helpful for learning
Weaknesses: writing a research paper about something relating to water in the 20th c. is fairly restrictive
Professor Lee and my classmates were fantastic! Our discussions were very lively and passionate.

Strengths: reading were informative and interesting, syllabus was well planned, discussions were engaging 
Weaknesses: discussions could sometimes get a little quiet and then other times were would be a line of several students waiting to speak, but this was definitely a result of zoom where it is tough to get a naturally flowing conversation.

Great overview of how natural resource policy connects to overarching political structures. Could have explored nuance a bit more closely (e.g. why would one policy not *necessarily* have been indicative of some larger trend or vice versa). Also readings during weeks 4-6 seemed a bit repetitive

Strengths: Fantastic class and lively discussion. The work was interesting and engaging. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes lacked structure or background info on the issues we discussed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom seminar discussions will always be a bit tricky, but this one went very smoothly. The Canvas discussion board reading responses before class were a great element.
Professor Lee's ability to lead a seminar was amazing.
I wished the seminars were recorded so that we could go back and review what was said in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. It's a good deal of work, but if you're interested in history or the environment or just want a fun seminar, this is a very cool class that uses water to demonstrate lots of themes in 20th century history, both in the US and around the world.
ABSOLUTELY! Professor Lee's feedback was THE BEST FEEDBACK I'VE RECEIVED IN MY 3 YEARS AT YALE! If you want to find someone who is passionate about what he teaches, Professor Lee is the person!

Yes! Anyone interested in water, the environment, history, or social justice to take this class. Honestly, I would recommend this class to any Yale student because it touches on so many different topics and disciplines.
I would certainly recommend this class to another student because it is engaging and water connects to so many issues that a student in any major would enjoy this class.
Yes! You learn a lot about the role of water in state formation and environmental destruction.

extras.title:
HIST 408J 01
        Global Water in the Modern Era
